questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with chronic cough, bronchiectasis, lower limb lymphedema, and the following nail findings. What are these nail findings called?
questions.solution:
This is an image showing yellow nails, and this feature is a component of the yellow nail syndrome. They can also occur due to secondary infection with Pseudomonas spp. or Candida spp.

Yellow nail syndrome consists of the triad of yellow nail discoloration, pulmonary manifestations (chronic cough, bronchiectasis, pleural effusion), and lower limb lymphedema. Chronic sinusitis is frequently associated with the triad.

The characteristic finding is the development of thickened and excessively curved, yellow nails. There is an almost complete stoppage of nail growth.

Other options -

Option A: Leukonychia is a white discoloration of the nail. True leukonychia occurs due to dysfunction of the nail matrix. Apparent leukonychia is seen due to pallor of the nail bed, as seen in chronic anemia, edema, and vascular diseases.

Option C: Terry's nails are a type of apparent leukonychia of nearly the entire nail, with obliteration of the lunula, and a narrow band of normal, pink nail bed at the distal border. They are commonly associated with liver cirrhosis, congestive heart failure, and diabetes. 

Option D: In Lindsay's nails, also known as half-and-half nails, the proximal portion of the nail is white and the distal half is red, pink, or brown, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. It is a rare finding and can be seen in yellow nail syndrome, chronic renal failure, Crohn's disease, Kawasaki's disease, Behcet's disease, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, zinc deficiency, citrullinemia, pellagra, HIV infection, and even in healthy persons.

Maybe, picking the obvious answer is a good idea, sometimes!

questions.text: How does the Jendrassik manoeuvre reinforce the knee jerk reflex?

choices.text: Activates group 1b nerve fibres in tendon
Decreases activity of group 1a nerve fibres

questions.solution:
Jendrassik's maneuver reinforces the knee-jerk reflex by increasing the gamma motor neuron discharge from the spinal cord. Increased gamma motor discharge increases the sensitivity of group 1a nerve fibers in the muscle spindles to stretch. Increased activity of the group 1a afferents enhances deep tendon reflexes, including the knee jerk reflex.

The maneuver can also enhance reflexes by distracting the subject and preventing conscious inhibition.

Other options:

Group 1b fibres in the Golgi tendon organ are activated in the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. On examination, she appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed pH - 7.00, blood sugar level- 500 mg/dL, and ketonuria. What type of breathing pattern can be observed in this case?

choices.text: Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release.
Regular deep respirations with periods of apnea

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with severe dehydration, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis(pH-7.00) is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The type of breathing pattern that can be seen in a case of diabetic ketoacidosis is a deep and rapid breathing pattern (Kussmaul breathing).

Normally, the H+ ions from acids in our body are buffered with various mechanisms. But in cases where acid production is high like in diabetic ketoacidosis and sepsis, the buffering capacity is exceeded. The resulting acidosis stimulates respiration and decreases alveolar CO2 in order to produce a compensatory fall in the H+ ions.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The triad of DKA includes hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. Clinical manifestations of diabetic ketoacidosis include dehydration, tachypnea with deep, sighing respiration (Kussmaul breathing), nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion, and drowsiness.

Patients with DKA typically have:

  • Hyperglycemia (blood glucose >250 mg/dl)
  • Venous pH < 7.3 or serum bicarbonate <18 mmol/L
  • Ketonemia or ketonuria

Signs of ketoacidosis: 

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Prolonged Q-T interval
  • Diminished neurocognitive function
  • Coma
Other options:
 
Option A: Apneusis is characterized by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release. It is seen in mid-pontine level lesions with cut vagi.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option C: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 54-year-old female patient with non-productive cough, exertional dyspnoea, and fatigue, you notice cyanosis and clubbing. On further examination, you hear late inspiratory velcro crackles at lung bases that are unaltered by coughing and the pulmonary function test showed a restrictive deficit. Which of the following conditions should this typical clinical picture prompt you to suspect?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) should be suspected in this patient.

ILD or diffuse parenchymal lung disease  is a heterogeneous collection of disorders that share a common presentation (dyspnea), physical findings (late inspiratory crackles), and chest radiographs (septal thickening and reticulonodular changes)

ILD occurs in patients aged more than 60 years and is common in women. They may present with an insidious onset of progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough. Late inspiratory velcro crackles on the lung base are one of the physical findings present in ILD. Cyanosis and clubbing are seen in advanced diseases.

In ILD, Pulmonary function test show a restrictive deficit. 

Based on the histopathological pattern on lung biopsy-

 Type of ILD Histologic pattern seen
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia A fibrotic or cellular pattern of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis associated lung disease
Systematic sclerosis-associated ILD Both UIP and NSIP
 Sarcoidosis Non caseating granuloma

Other options:

Bronchiolitis, bronchiectasis, and bronchial asthma are obstructive lung diseases. Pulmonary function test show obstructive pattern. 

Note: Velcro crackles may also be heard in case of radiation pneumonitis. Also, it may be difficult to reliably distinguish the same from crackles of pulmonary edema. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia

    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: You would perform a Gutzmann’s pressure test for diagnosing which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Gutzmann’s pressure test is done in a case of puberphonia.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and low tone voice can be produced. This is known as the Gutzmann’s pressure test.

Puberphonia:

  • Condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males.
  • They continue to speak in the pre-pubertal high-pitched voice.
  • The treatment is speech therapy

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).
 
UMNs refer to corticospinal tract neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Injury to UMNs lead to:
  • Spasticity
  • Hypertonia 
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of all the toes.
 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text: Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy is defined as lymph nodes more than ___ cm in size, in ___ or more extra inguinal sites persisting for ___ or more months without an obvious cause. The respective answers are:
questions.solution:
Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy is defined as lymph nodes more than 1 cm in size, in 2 or more areas persisting for 3 or more months.

Generalized lymphadenopathy is frequently associated with disorders such as:

  • Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus [EBV])
  • Cytomegalovirus [CMV]
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • AIDS
  • Other viral infections
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), and mixed connective tissue disease
  • Acute and chronic lymphocytic leukemias and malignant lymphomas

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of breathlessness after walking about 100m. According to the Modified medical research council scale which grade does this patient belong to?
questions.solution:
A patient who stops for breath after walking about 100 m belongs to grade 3 according to the Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnoea scale.

The Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale is used to classify the severity of symptoms in respiratory diseases, specifically COPD.

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

  • Grade 0 -Not troubled by breathlessness, except with strenuous exercise 
  • Grade 1 - Shortness of breath walking on level ground or walking up a slight hill
  • Grade 2 - Walks slower than people of similar age on level ground due to breathlessness, or has to stop to rest when walking at their own pace on level ground.
  • Grade 3 - Stops to rest after walking about 100 yards(~91m) or after walking a few minutes on level ground
  • Grade 4 - Too breathless to leave the house, or breathless with activities of daily living (e.g., dressing/ undressing)

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of drooling of saliva and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Bell's Palsy is suspected. When the patient is asked to close the affected eye, the sign given in the image below can be seen. What is the likely cause?

choices.text: Left sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy
Right sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy
Left sided UMN type of facial nerve palsy
Right sided UMN type of facial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario history of drooling of saliva, deviation of the angle of the mouth, and the image showing Bell's phenomenon of left eye are suggestive of a left-sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy. It presents with an inability to close the eye, and when the patient attempts to close the eye, eyeball turns up and out. This is known as the Bell's phenomenon.

Bell's palsy is an acute onset idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis. It is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Other features include drooling of saliva and facial asymmetry. There may be noise intolerance and a loss of taste sensation.

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.

The following image shows a patient with Bell's palsy. 

Difference between UMN and LMN facial palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy Absent Present

questions.text: Which of the following Korotkoff sounds corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in a patient with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Muffled sound corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in aortic regurgitation.

In aortic regurgitation, the pulse pressure is widened and the Korotkoff sounds often do not disappear even when the sphygmomanometer cuff is fully deflated. Hence, diastolic pressure is recorded at the pressure that corresponds to muffling of korotkoff sounds.

Disappearance of sounds

Corresponds to Diastolic BP

NOTE- K-4 (muffled sound) corresponds to DBP in-

  • Adults after exercise
  • Children
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Patients with arteriovenous fistulas for hemodialysis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of chest pain which worsens on deep inspiration, non-productive cough, and dyspnea. The chest x-ray is given below. What will be percussion notes just above the level of the suspected pathology?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario history of chest pain which worsens on deep inspiration, non-productive cough, dyspnea and X-ray showing obliteration of costophrenic angle is suggestive of pleural effusion. On examination, there will be sub tympanic note on percussion above the level of pleural effusion.

Percussion notes

  • Tympanic note - Drum Like Note - Stomach, Intestine, subcutaneous Emphysema(Option A)
  • Subtympanic(Skodiac)note - Boxy Quality note - Just above pleural effusion
  • Hyper-resonant note - Note quality is between normal and tympanic - Pneumothorax, Bilateral emphysema(Option D)
  • Impaired note - Seen in airless areas - Lung fibrosis, Lung collapse
  • Dull note - Seen in Consolidation, Thick pleura
  • Stony dull note - Pain is felt over the pleximeter finger with a plexor finger feeling resistance - seen in Large pleural effusion (Option B)

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to

  • Excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity.
  • Decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics.

Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness, chest pain, and syncopal attacks on and off for 3 months. Echocardiography showed an abnormality of the cardiac valve. Identify the valvular lesion and the associated murmur from the below image that depicts the heart sounds and murmur of the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a systolic murmur (occurring in the interval between S1 and S2) are suggestive of aortic stenosis and the associated systolic murmur. 

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It is caused by rheumatic heart disease or by the calcification of the normal aortic valve or a congenital bicuspid valve. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decrease in stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (pulsus parvus), which slowly rises and has a delayed peak (pulsus tardus)—a pattern best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of aortic stenosis are exertional dyspnea due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction, angina pectoris due to the combination of the increased oxygen demand and reduced supply, syncope due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation, which lead to a reduction in cerebral perfusion.

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after the first heart sound (S1), increases in intensity toward the middle of the ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

A systolic ejection click can be heard in young patients with a bicuspid aortic valve, but disappears as the valves become calcified. A2 and P2 may be heard at the same time, or A2 may follow P2, resulting in the paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2). The fourth heart sound (S4) is often heard at the apex, indicating the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Other options:

In mitral stenosis, a diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

Other murmurs: 

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo-blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. Wide splitting of S2 may occur due to the premature closure of the aortic valve. A low-pitched, third heart sound (S3) may occur following A2. S4 can also be audible in patients with acute severe MR.

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent, and occasionally, S4 also may be heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

 

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  1. Mitral regurgitation

  • Best heard at the apex
  • Radiates to axilla or base
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • A2 is not heard at the apex

  2. Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Best heard at lower left sternal border
  • Radiates to the epigastrium and right sternal border
  • Increases in intensity during inspiration
  • Prominent c-v waves seen in JVP

  3. Ventricular septal defect

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of breathlessness that worsen with exertion and fatiguability for a few months. Based on further workup, a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis was made. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in him due to this condition?

choices.text: Rise or a lack of fall in his JVP during inspiration
Sharp fall in his JVP during inspiration
Sharp rise followed by a sustained deep fall in JVP during expiration
Sharp fall followed by a rise in JVP during expiration

questions.solution:
In a patient with constrictive pericarditis, the clinical sign that is likely to be seen in JVP is Kussmaul’s sign. It is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis, although it has been reported in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy, massive pulmonary embolism, right ventricular infarction, and advanced left ventricular (LV) systolic heart failure. 

The pathophysiological mechanisms responsible for Kussmaul’s sign can be explained by conditions that cause right ventricular dysfunction, impair right ventricular filling, and raise atrial pressure. The inability of cardiac chambers to expand due to (1) hypoelasticity or inelasticity of the myocardium caused by conditions such as infection and fibrosis (restrictive cardiomyopathy) (2) mechanical compartmentalization by constrictive pericardial diseases (constrictive pericarditis), or (3) impaired right ventricular function resulting from right-sided myocardial infarction, impede effective right ventricular filling and cause a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text: On tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. This is known as ______
questions.solution:
In the Schwartz test, on tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. 

Perthe’s Test: The affected lower limb is wrapped in an elastic bandage, after ruling out arterial occlusive disease. The patient is then asked to walk around. Severe cramping pain arises if there is deep vein thrombosis. 

Modified Perthe’s Test: A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. In the presence of normal communicating and deep veins, the varicose veins will shrink. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. 

Morrisey’s cough impulse test: The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins. Now it is put to bed and the patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a Bruit may be heard on auscultation.

questions.text: Identify the lesions seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The lesions seen in the image are Spider angiomas.

Spider angiomas (also known as spider naevus or spider telangiectasias) consist of a central arteriole, about pin-headed in size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs. They are seen in a case of liver cirrhosis. Although the exact cause of spider angiomas is not known, many hypotheses have been put forward. Important among those are direct vasodilatory effects of alcohol, substance P, hyperestrogenism, and inadequate hepatic metabolism of steroid hormones. Spider naevus is also seen in pregnancy and with the use of estrogen-containing pills, further associating it with a hyperestrogenic state.

Other findings due to inadequate hepatic metabolism of steroid hormones leading to a hyperestrogenic state are:

  • Testicular atrophy(<4ml), loss of chest hair, and gynecomastia in males
  • Menstrual irregularities in females
  • Decreased libido
  • Palmar erythema: Palmar erythema is symmetrical, bilateral, non-painful, non-itchy, and slightly warm redness of the palms(vasodilation). The center of the palm is usually spared.

Signs and symptoms of liver cirrhosis:

Symptom/Sign Description Pathophysiology
Jaundice Yellowish discoloration of the skin, sclera, and mucous membranes Hepatic excretory dysfunction
Ascites Accumulation of fluid in peritoneal space Portal Hypertension and Hypoalbuminemia due to decreased synthetic function of the liver
Esophageal varices and hemorrhoids Dilated veins at the levels of portosystemic shunting Portal Hypertension
Caput medusae Prominent veins radiating from the umbilicus Portal Hypertension
Spider Angiomata Central arteriole with radiating capillaries that blanch on pressure Hyperestrogenic state
Palmar Erythema Reddish discoloration of the palms, sparing the center Hyperestrogenic state
Gynaecomastia, loss of male hair pattern Benign proliferation of glandular breast tissue in men Hyperestrogenic state
Hypogonadism Reduced testicular volume, infertility  Hyperestrogenic state
Thrombocytopenia Decreased platelet counts Hypersplenism and decreased production of thrombopoietin in the liver
Coagulopathies Petechiae, purpura, and bleeding Decreased synthetic function of the liver (coagulation factors)
Dupuytren's contracture Fibrosis and contracture of the palmar fascia Increased oxidative stress 
Asterexis and Hepatic Encephalopathy Flapping motion of dorsiflexed hands, altered level of consciousness Dysregulated ammonia metabolism
Fetor hepaticus Sweet, pungent smell in breath Portosystemic shunting of volatile dimethylsulfide

questions.text: A patient who is comfortable at rest, but has symptoms on less than ordinary physical activity, with marked limitation of physical activity, is classified as ________.
questions.solution:
A patient who is comfortable at rest, but has symptoms on less than ordinary physical activity, with marked limitation of physical activity, should be classified as NYHA class III.

NYHA class Description
I
  • No limitation of physical activity
  • Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms
II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
III
  • Marked limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
IV
  • Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms or symptoms at rest

questions.text: During the ward rounds, you notice the notes on a patient file says dysdiadochokinesia present. To elicit this, which of the following would you ask the patient to perform?

choices.text: Stand with the feet close by and the eyes closed
Fix the eye on an object on one extreme of the room
Supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession
Walk heel to toe on a straight line without any support

questions.solution:
The patient should be asked to perform a rapid alternating movement like the supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession for eliciting dysdiadochokinesis.  Dysdiadochokinesia is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.

It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia. 

Standing with the feet close by and the eyes closed is used to check for Romberg sign. Walking heel to toe on a straight line without any support is known as the tandem walking test.

 

The following movement is the method to check for dysdiadochokinesis. The patient is showing normal movement, with no dysdiadochokinesis.
